newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Regulator says Israel stock market still in crisis.
newsitem.headline: Regulator says Israel stock market still in crisis.

text.p: The Israeli stock market has not experienced a real recovery, despite rallying share prices, the chairman of Israel's securities watchdog warned in the authority's annual report released on Sunday.

"One must be careful that the signs of a re-awakening seen in the bourse recently are not enough to signal an end to the capital markets crisis," Arie Mientkavich, chairman of the Securities Authority, said in a cover letter to the report.
Sharp increases in share prices, he said, usually indicated problems in the market and not underlying strength.

"When the weight of long-term savings in the capital markets is declining, the problems of institutional investors have not been solved and only a small number of needed measures have been undertaken by the government and other authorities, it is too early to speak about recovery," Mientkavich said.
Since the start of November, the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange's Mishtanim index has risen about 40 percent following a three-year slump that began in early 1994.

Mientkavich said that among the steps needed to create a "fair and functioning market" were structural changes in the bodies responsible for securities regulation, measures to deconcentrate control of the market and better internal controls among market institutions.
He said the government also had to rethink its practice of issuing high-interest non-tradable bonds to the pension funds.
